nodes.text: The difference in speed between reading color names and naming colors is primarily due to differing strengths of learned associations produced by training, and this difference can be measured as interference between simultaneous word and color stimuli

Method: Construct stimuli that present both a word naming a color and an ink color that may differ, and use paired tests to measure interference: reading color names printed in conflicting ink versus printed in black, and naming ink colors when words name other colors versus naming colors printed as shapes

Method: Use serial reaction tests with 100 or 200 reactions per sheet, counterbalance form order and control lighting and instructions, record times with stopwatch and apply small corrections for uncorrected errors

Experiment 1 design: Measure effect of interfering color stimuli on reading color names by comparing reading color-name words printed in conflicting colors (RCNd) to reading same words printed in black (RCNb)

Experiment 2 design: Measure effect of interfering word stimuli on naming colors by comparing naming ink colors of words printed in conflicting colors (NCWd) to naming colors presented as colored shapes (NC)

Result: In Experiment 1, reading color-name words printed in conflicting colors took on average 2.3 seconds longer per 100 words (about 5.6 percent) than reading the same words in black, a difference not statistically reliable

Result: In Experiment 2, naming ink colors of words that name other colors increased mean time from 63.3 sec to 110.3 sec per 100 items (an increase of 47.0 seconds or 74 percent), a large and reliable interference effect

Claim: Associations between word stimuli and the reading response are stronger and more effective than associations between color stimuli and the specific response of naming colors, likely because reading has more consistent practiced mapping

Experiment 3 design: Provide repeated practice (daily sessions, 200 reactions per day across multiple days) in naming ink colors of conflicting words (NCWd) to test effects of practice on interference and on performance in both NCWd and other tests

Conclusion: The large asymmetry of interference (weak effect of color on reading vs strong effect of words on color naming) supports the hypothesis that differential training history produces stronger word-reading associations than color-naming associations

Result: Practice on NCWd (eight days) produced a 33.9 percent reduction in time on NCWd itself (gain 16.8 seconds) but only a 13.9 percent reduction on NC, indicating partial transfer; practice increased group variability on NCWd and increased interference of color on reading (RCNd)

Claim: Practice can modify interference asymmetrically: strengthening color-naming responses reduces but does not eliminate word-to-color interference and can increase color-to-word interference and group variability

Result: Sex differences observedâ€”females were faster at naming colors than males; practice reduced but did not eliminate this sex difference, suggesting at least partial contribution of learned experience

Conclusion: The difference in speed between reading color names and naming colors can be satisfactorily accounted for by differences in prior training and habitual responses; colors evoke a variety of responses while words evoke a specific practiced reading response

Limitation: The experiments use college student volunteers with specific color sets and short practice schedules; individual differences, initial variability, and limited stimulus set may constrain generality
